title: Push to Disclose Foreign Agents Could Ensnare Corporate Executives
text:
The U.S. Justice Department’s efforts to ramp up enforcement of a World War II-era statute requiring the disclosure of political work done on behalf of foreign governments could have implications for a range of actors, including corporate executives.

The department Wednesday unveiled a new online filing system for so-called foreign agents, which it says will make compliance with the law easier. In a briefing with reporters on the system, an official said the law didn’t just apply to lobbyists, but also to business executives who may get requests from foreign governments for help with policy-related objectives.

“Nobody should think, ‘I’m not a lobbyist or lawyer, therefore I don’t have to abide by the statute,’” said Assistant Attorney General John Demers. “There are nontraditional groups that need to be careful of the statute and what they are asked to do by foreign governments.”

Newsletter Sign-up

The Foreign Agents Registration Act, or FARA, entered the spotlight in the midst of former special counsel Robert Mueller’s investigation into Russian interference in the 2016 election.

While much of the focus has been on some of Washington’s most familiar professional groups—including lawyers, political consultants and public relations firms—lawyers who advise on the foreign agent law say corporate executives in nonpolitical sectors also should be on notice.

“This is not an issue just for lobbying firms and public relations firms because FARA sweeps very broadly and applies to corporations as well nonprofit groups,” said Robert Kelner, a partner at the law firm Covington & Burling LLP. “They’re all in the crosshairs.”

Mr. Kelner, who said he has advised on the foreign agents law for more than 20 years, previously represented former President Trump national security adviser Mike Flynn, one of the targets of Mr. Mueller’s investigation. Mr. Flynn, who pleaded guilty to lying to the FBI in December 2017, admitted to making false statements on government forms about his work on behalf of Turkey.

The Justice Department decided to step up enforcement of the foreign agents law in 2015. It says its efforts will lead to a doubling in the number of registrants annually as of 2016, if current rates continue.

Yet despite a promising start that led to Mr. Flynn’s guilty plea and another by former Trump campaign chairman Paul Manafort —who pleaded guilty in 2018 to a conspiracy related to his failure to register under FARA for his work on behalf of Ukraine—the department has suffered several recent setbacks.

A federal judge Tuesday overturned the conviction of a former business partner to Mr. Flynn. The same day, prosecutors told defense attorneys that they had closed probes into two Washington lobbying firms and wouldn’t bring criminal charges.

Those developments came three weeks after jurors acquitted Democratic lawyer Gregory Craig of a charge that he lied to the unit that enforces the foreign agent law.

Responding to the setbacks Wednesday, Mr. Demers said the Justice Department was still committed to rooting out covert foreign influence. He said the department was weighing its next steps with respect to the judge’s ruling in the case against Mr. Flynn’s business partner, Bijan Kian, who was convicted in July of conspiracy and acting as an unregistered agent of Turkey.

An official who leads the unit charged with enforcing the foreign agent law told a group of lawyers Wednesday that the Justice Department was focused on improving compliance through education and awareness, in addition to building criminal and civil cases. Law firms and other entities need to make sure FARA is one of the statutes they take into account when designing compliance policies and procedures, said Brandon Van Grack, a veteran prosecutor whose appointment was announced by Mr. Demers in March. Mr. Van Grack previously served on Mr. Mueller’s special counsel team.

Mr. Kelner and other lawyers who advise on FARA also maintain that the focus on foreign agents would continue.

“With FARA, we’re in that early stage where companies just now are beginning to realize it applies to them,” he said. “It’s a minefield for multinational corporations that have contacts with foreign governments.”

Write to Dylan Tokar at dylan.tokar@wsj.com
description: Efforts to ramp up enforcement of a statute requiring the disclosure of political work done for foreign governments could have implications for corporate executives.
